channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Hamas Names an Architect of Oct. 7 Attacks as New Political Leader
item.description: Hamas announced that Yahya Sinwar would take over as the group’s political leader after the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh in Iran.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Bangladesh Prime Minister’s Sheikh Hasina’s Chaotic Final Hours
item.description: As masses of people converged, angry at the killing of protesters, Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina insisted that she could hold on, which military leaders said would mean spilling far more blood.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Shayeza Walid and Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: A vandalized image of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina in the aftermath of her hasty departure from Bangladesh.

item.title: Venezuela’s Strongman Was Confident of Victory. Then Came the Shock.
item.description: Venezuela’s government believed its control of all levers of power would give the country’s authoritarian president an Election Day victory. A rebellion by its supporters undid the plan.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shortly after midnight on the day of the election, the government-controlled electoral council declared President Nicolás Maduro the winner, without providing any vote tallies.

item.title: Muhammad Yunus to Head Bangladesh Interim Government
item.description: The new government was being formed a day after Bangladesh’s longtime leader, facing fierce protests, fled the country.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat, Shayeza Walid and Anupreeta Das
item.media:description: Muhammad Yunus in Dhaka, Bangladesh, in January.

item.title: Can Freed Russian Dissidents Help Energize Opposition Movement?
item.description: The release of activists like Ilya Yashin gives new hope to a movement in which various groups are often at war with each other. But many have doubts.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Ekaterina Bodyagina and Alina Lobzina
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Freed Russian dissidents, from left: Ilya Yashin, Andrei Pivovarov and Vladimir Kara-Murza, arriving at a conference in Bonn, Germany on Friday, a day after they were released in a prisoner swap.

item.title: Iran Executes Protester Reza Rasaei After Trial Condemned by Rights Groups
item.description: Weeks after Iran elected a reformist leader, the authorities executed Reza Rasaei, who was arrested during protests that swept the country in 2022.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Antigovernment protests swept across Iran in 2022. A man who was arrested during that period was executed by the Iranian authorities on Tuesday.

item.title: Long Battle for a Ruined City Takes a Desperate Turn
item.description: Ukrainian troops are engaged in a harsh struggle for Toretsk, a strategic city in eastern Ukraine that has been under relentless assault by Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: An artillery unit of Ukraine’s 95th Separate Air Assault Brigade firing a howitzer last month at Russian troops trying to capture Toretsk, in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Waiting for a Wider War, Lebanese Civilians Feel Helpless
item.description: Hezbollah’s conflict with Israel has already damaged south Lebanon. Now it could escalate, regardless of what anyone else in Lebanon thinks.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Hwaida Saad and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah members and supporters mourned the deaths of Amer Dagher and his two sisters, Fawzia and Taghreed, who were killed in their home in an Israeli attack on July 15.

item.title: ‘Why Trash Your Own Town?’ An English City Reckons With a Riot.
item.description: Days after an angry crowd marauded through Sunderland, people in the industrial port city are trying to make sense of what just happened.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Police officers were deployed on horseback to try to control the unrest in Sunderland, northeastern England, on Friday.

item.title: Sheikh Hasina Thought Her Grip on Bangladesh Was Unbreakable
item.description: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina, who once brought democratic hope to Bangladesh, turned increasingly autocratic and met her downfall in a crackdown on protesters.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sheikh Hasina, who grew more authoritarian as prime minister over the years, fled into exile to India after widespread protests.

item.title: Court in Germany Fines Protester for ‘River to the Sea’ Chant
item.description: A judge said the phrase, used at a pro-Palestinian rally in Berlin days after the Oct. 7 attacks, “could only be understood as a denial of Israel’s right to exist.”
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:description: A pro-Gaza rally in Berlin in October. The phrase “From the river to the sea, Palestine will be free” has disputed meanings and a complicated history.

item.title: Why Has Hu Xijin, a Chinese Nationalist, Suddenly Gone Silent?
item.description: Hu Xijin’s tens of millions of followers have heard nothing from him since late July. Some think one of his posts praising Beijing may have backfired.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hu Xijin in Beijing in 2019.

item.title: As Ukraine Collects Medals in Paris, Its Sports Pipeline Is in Tatters
item.description: Facilities have been battered. Coaches are in short supply. Children have moved abroad. Ukraine faces a long hard road toward rebuilding its athletic programs.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman, Oleksandr Chubko and Chang W. Lee
item.media:description: Ganna Gatsko practicing with a javelin in June at Spartak Stadium in Brovary, Ukraine.

item.title: How the Runner Grant Fisher Made It to the Paris Olympics
item.description: All elite athletes make changes to their lives to keep their careers moving forward. For the American distance runner Grant Fisher, the key to success was in his past.
item.dc:creator: Scott Cacciola
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grant Fisher, right, won bronze in Paris with the help of Mike Scannell, his coach for the Olympics and also his mentor in high school.

item.title: Fear Stalks Israel’s Communities on the Front Lines With Lebanon
item.description: As tensions again escalate with Hezbollah, Israelis face the prospect of another “lost year” in the evacuated north.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A soldier enters a bomb shelter in the evacuated Kibbutz Snir in northern Israel, near the border with Lebanon.

item.title: How Belarus Was Left Out of a Prisoner Swap Between Russia and the West
item.description: While Belarus played a role in the sweeping prisoner exchange last week, none of the 1,400 people classified as political prisoners in the country by a human rights group were freed.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Tomas Dapkus
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The exiled Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, second right, held a photo of her jailed husband, Sergei Tikhanovsky, during a protest in Vilnius, Lithuania, in March. Others held photos of other Belarusian opposition figures.

item.title: After French Rail Sabotage, Some See Signs of a Murky ‘Ultraleft’
item.description: Experts say the arson attacks before the opening of the Paris Olympics bear the hallmarks of insurrectionary anarchists opposed to the state.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Soldiers patrol outside Gare du Nord train station. There have been no arrests for the coordinated arson attacks that briefly disrupted rail travel for hundreds of thousands of travelers before the Olympics opened.

item.title: Indian Wrestler Vinesh Phogat Disqualified From Paris Olympics Gold Medal Match
item.description: Indian officials said she failed to make her weight class by a few grams. Last year, she was the face of a protest against a powerful Indian sports official.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Vinesh Phogat of India competing against Yusneylis Guzmán Lopez of Cuba during the semifinal match at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday.

item.title: Suga, of BTS, Apologizes for Riding Electric Scooter While Drunk
item.description: The artist had his driver’s license revoked and may face disciplinary action after failing a breath test, his agency said.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Suga, a member of the K-pop group BTS, in 2022.

item.title: Capturing the Split Seconds Between Victory and Defeat
item.description: Faced with the challenge of quickly recapping Olympic events, The Times creates its own animated versions of competitions. The internet loves them.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: Nick Bartzokas, Alice Fang, John Huang, and Eden Weingart/The New York Times
item.media:description: For the past five Olympic Games, The Times has animated events from sports including track and field to help readers get caught up to speed.

item.title: The Olympics Have a Gap That Netflix Is Trying to Fill
item.description: New seasons of documentaries about running, gymnastics and basketball are being filmed this summer as part of a partnership with the International Olympic Committee.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A documentary crew for Netflix filmed American track and field athletes during a morning practice in Eaubonne, France, near Paris, last week.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Kamala Harris’s choice for vice president.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris with Tim Walz in Philadelphia on Tuesday.

item.title: Olympics: How the Ingebrigtsens Brought Speedsuits to Middle-Distance Running
item.description: Once an outfit strictly worn by sprinters, the single-piece speedsuit has become common among middle-distance runners. Its efficacy is beside the point.
item.dc:creator: Scott Cacciola
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway, right, has helped popularize speedsuits in the 1,500 meters. His brother Henrik pioneered the use of the suits in middle-distance running.

item.title: Can You Heal Olympic Heartbreak With Belated Medals?
item.description: A weight lifter walked away from his sport after a bitter loss in 2012. He and other athletes, including a U.S. figure skating team, will receive their medals in Paris.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeon competing in the London Olympics. After his Russian rival, Ruslan Albegov, secured third place, Jeon returned home and started a new life.

item.title: Olympic Boxer Imane Khelif Will Fight For a Gold Medal On Friday
item.description: Imane Khelif, of Algeria, moved past questions about her eligibility with a unanimous decision over her Thai opponent. She will now fight for a gold medal.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Imane Khelif of Algeria, right, won her semifinal match against Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand on Tuesday.

item.title: Hamas Elevates Gaza Leader Who Planned Oct. 7 Attacks to Top Post
item.description: The selection of Yahya Sinwar, a prime target of Israeli forces, to replace the assassinated Ismail Haniyeh consolidates authority in the hands of a hard-liner who is in hiding.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Aaron Boxerman, Euan Ward and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar will replace Ismail Haniyeh as the next head of Hamas’s political office. He is seen here in Gaza City in 2023.

item.title: Who Is Yahya Sinwar, Hamas’s New Political Leader?
item.description: Mr. Sinwar, one of the main architects of the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attack on Israel, has spent decades with the militant group, working his way to the top of its leadership.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar, in Gaza City in 2023, has long been viewed as one of Hamas’s most influential leaders, wielding outsize power while remaining mostly in hiding in underground tunnels.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Harris Picked a Running Mate
item.description: Plus, how breaking made it to the Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: Caroline Yang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tim Walz’s rural roots, liberal policies and buzzy takedowns of Donald Trump put him on the map.

item.title: E.P.A. Pulls Pesticide Dacthal From the Market Over Health Concerns
item.description: The herbicide, used widely on crops including broccoli and onions, can cause low birth weight and impaired brain development, regulators said.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: The product, known as Dacthal and DCPA, is commonly used on crops like broccoli, brussels sprouts, cabbage and onions.

item.title: Who Is Muhammad Yunus, the Next Leader of Bangladesh?
item.description: Mr. Yunus, who received the Nobel Peace Prize for his pioneering work in microfinance, is widely respected in Bangladesh. The ousted prime minister largely saw him as a threat.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.media:description: Muhammad Yunus and his Grameen Bank received the 2006 Nobel Peace Prize for their efforts to provide financial opportunities to the poor.

item.title: The Tiny Chinese Restaurant That Became an Olympic Hot Spot
item.description: A few blocks from the table tennis venue, a restaurant has become an unofficial (and unlikely) clubhouse for fans, team officials and athletes.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh and Weiyi Cai
item.media:credit: Photographs by Weiyi Cai/The New York Times
item.media:description: For the past two weeks, Tang Zhongqiu’s narrow restaurant, Yang Xiao Chu, has been transformed into a bustling, unofficial hangout for Olympic table tennis fans.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Ava Pellor for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. stock market saw its biggest daily decline in nearly two years.

item.title: To Save His Shrinking City, a Mayor Turns to Koreans Uprooted by Stalin
item.description: Like many South Korean cities, Jecheon is being eroded by rapid aging and rock-bottom birthrates. Can ethnic Korean migrants from Central Asia turn it around?
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Jun Michael Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jecheon, like many other small cities in South Korea, is being eroded by rapid aging and low birthrates.

item.title: As Israel Braces for Iran’s Retaliation, Diplomats Scramble
item.description: President Biden convened his national security team and spoke with King Abdullah II of Jordan, and foreign ministers from Islamic countries plan to gather in Saudi Arabia on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Hamas and Hezbollah drove through the streets of Saida, Lebanon, following tributes for the slain Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh and the Hezbollah commander Fuad Shukr on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Troops in Iraq Are Wounded in Rocket Attack on Air Base
item.description: The attack late Monday resembled previous ones carried out by Iraqi armed groups, backed by Iran, which have targeted the base repeatedly over the past nine months.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: U.N. Fires Nine Aid Workers Accused of Taking Part in Oct. 7 Attack, but Clears 10 Others
item.description: Israel accused 19 UNRWA employees of playing a role in the Hamas-led raids that set off the war. Investigators cleared 10 for lack of evidence, but said the other nine “may have been involved.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Ephrat Livni
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians receiving food aid at the UNRWA center in Rafah, Gaza, in January.

item.title: Violent U.K. Riots Pose Challenge to Keir Starmer’s New Government
item.description: The new Labour government’s strong law-and-order approach to the violence has mostly spared it from criticism, even from the Conservatives, who only recently left power. But challenges remain.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer held an emergency meeting last week to discuss anti-immigrant riots following a stabbing attack that was wrongly attributed to a migrant.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Global Markets Fell
item.description: Plus, LeBron James at the Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: On the floor of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

item.title: Mexican Reporter Gunned Down, Even With a Security Detail at His Side
item.description: Alejandro Martínez had received so many threats that the Mexican government appointed him protection. On Sunday, he was shot and killed and his bodyguards wounded.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Police officers outside the hospital where the journalist Alejandro Martínez was taken after being shot, in Celaya, Mexico.

item.title: Facing Mass Protests, Bangladesh Leader Quits, Setting Up Power Struggle
item.description: Demonstrators defied a curfew, expecting another in a series of bloody crackdowns, but instead Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina fled.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat, Shayeza Walid and Anupreeta Das
item.media:credit: K M Asad/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters stormed the official residence of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina as she fled the country, in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Monday.

item.title: Boxing Officials Offer Little Clarity on Olympic Eligibility Dispute
item.description: Two Olympians whose eligibility to compete as women at the Paris Games has come under scrutiny will fight for medals on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: The head of the International Boxing Association, Umar Kremlev, on video screen, claimed blood tests had proved two athletes in the women’s boxing competition were men but provided no evidence.

item.title: Bangladesh Protesters Swarm Sheikh Hasina’s Residence After Prime Minister Flees
item.description: Looters made off with furniture, bedding and potted plants.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson

item.title: How Did Simone Biles Become the G.O.A.T.?
item.description: She sealed her legacy with four medals at the Paris Games. She created it by being herself and going at her own pace.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur

item.title: Why Is Iran Expected to Attack Israel? Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Iran has vowed to retaliate for the killing of a senior Hamas leader in Tehran last week, an attack for which it has blamed Israel.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iranians gathered in Tehran last week after the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, a top Hamas leader.

item.title: He Was Freed From a Brutal Russian Jail. Here’s Why He Wanted to Stay.
item.description: The dissident Ilya Yashin calls his release in a prisoner swap last week an ‘illegal expulsion’ by Russia that damages his ability to be heard at home.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The Russian dissident Ilya Yashin at a news conference in Germany after his release last week. People in Russia “hear you much better when you’re there,” he said later.

item.title: Myanmar Rebels Gain Regional Military Base in Lashio, a Major Win
item.description: The seizure of the military’s northeastern command post gives the resistance control of a city and airport on a crucial trade corridor to China.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar
item.media:description: Soldiers of the Myanmar National Democratic Alliance Army patrolling in the Kokang region in 2015.

item.title: Pentagon Hands Over Last Base in Niger as Extremism Spreads in the Sahel
item.description: Relations between the two countries soured after a coup last year. Now the United States is scrambling to find new security partners.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Just under 400 American troops withdrew from a base in Niamey, Niger’s capital, earlier this year.

item.title: Biles’s Small Slip Stalls Medal Run in Paris Olympics
item.description: Four of the eight gymnasts fell off the beam, including Simone Biles and Sunisa Lee, the other American in the event. Alice D’Amato of Italy won the gold medal.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Simone Biles and several other competitors fell off the beam during the final on Monday.

item.title: Riots Break Out Across UK: What to Know
item.description: The country begins a new week on edge after anti-immigrant riots, fanned by disinformation from the far right, broke out in cities across Britain.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Anti-immigration protesters clashed with police officers in Rotherham, England, on Sunday.

item.title: How Did Flavor Flav Become a Hype Man for the U.S. Women’s Water Polo Team?
item.description: The rapper has become a self-appointed hype man and benefactor to the U.S. women’s team in Paris. He plans to keep the poolside party going into 2028.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: “They know deep down in their hearts and they know way in the back of their mind that Flav is right there for us,” America’s newest water polo superfan said.

item.title: How Will the Bangladesh Army Respond to Student Protests?
item.description: The military has a history of coups and counter coups. But in this showdown, it has seemed uncomfortable with the police crackdown on protesters.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Shayeza Walid
item.media:description: Bangladeshi soldiers with a cutout of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina last month. Though she has assiduously courted the army’s loyalty, the military has seemed troubled by the recent crackdown.

item.title: How Norway Became a Summer and Winter Olympics Powerhouse
item.description: With money from an oil boom, Norway, a force at the Winter Olympics for generations, is now churning out elite performers in track, soccer and other sports, too.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith and David B. Torch
item.media:credit: David B. Torch for The New York Times

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Kamala Harris’s search for a running mate.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris is expected to announce her running mate on Monday.

item.title: Japan Needs Foreign Workers. It’s Just Not Sure It Wants Them to Stay.
item.description: Foreign employees have become much more visible in Japan. But policies designed only for short-term stays may hurt the country in the global competition for labor.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Winda Zahra, a worker from Indonesia, with a resident at a care home in Maebashi, the capital of Gunma Prefecture in central Japan.

item.title: How the 9/11 Plea Deal Came Undone
item.description: A case that had mostly drifted from public consciousness in 12 years of proceedings is back in the spotlight and no closer to trial.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III reversed the plea deal agreement made by a senior Defense Department official whom he had appointed.

item.title: After a photo finish, Noah Lyles waits, and waits, and then claims the title of world’s fastest man.
item.description: Noah Lyles came from behind to beat out Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg, Ben Shpigel, Gabriela Bhaskar and Daniel Berehulak

item.title: Monday Briefing: A Tense Wait in Israel
item.description: Plus, philanthropy with a dark twist.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Tehran last week after Ismail Haniyeh was assassinated in Iran.

item.title: A weekend ride through Paris. Prizes for the first three finishers.
item.description: The Olympic road cycling events, open for all to watch, end in a sprint to the finish.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Das, James Hill and Chang W. Lee
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: How Two Russian Spies Went Deep Undercover With Their Children
item.description: A couple planted as sleeper spies in Slovenia posed as an Argentine art dealer and an entrepreneur. They were caught in December 2022 and sent to Moscow in a sweeping prisoner exchange last week.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Manca Juvan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Russian Embassy in Ljubljana, Slovenia. Russia has a long history of investing heavily in so-called illegals, spies who burrow deep into target countries over many years.

item.title: Israeli Strike on Gaza Shelter Kills at Least 30
item.description: An Israeli airstrike in Gaza City killed at least 30 people, according to a Palestinian emergency agency and local media outlets. Israel said it targeted Hamas “command and control centers.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Iyad Abuheweila and Ameera Harouda
item.media:description: In a still image taken from a video, Palestinians carried a person at the site of an Israeli strike on Sunday on a school sheltering displaced people in Gaza City.
